content: The "Edward William Brooke III Congressional Gold Medal Act" recognizes Senator Brooke as the first African American elected by popular vote to the US Senate, serving two terms from 1967 to 1979. He made significant contributions to consumer protection, housing discrimination, and air pollution legislation. In 1962, Edward William Brooke III made history as the first African American to be elected Attorney General of Massachusetts, the second highest office in the state. He was known for his fearless prosecution of organized crime and served as a Republican in a strongly Democratic state. Raised in Washington, DC, he achieved pioneering accomplishments in public service. Senator Brooke's advocacy for self-government and congressional voting rights for Washington, DC stems from his personal experiences as a native Washingtonian. He served in the segregated 366th Infantry Regiment during World War II, achieving the rank of captain and receiving honors. After the war, he attended Boston University. Senator Brooke graduated from Boston University School of Law in 1949 and became a leader in Congress on critical issues such as the Vietnam War, civil rights, apartheid in South Africa, the Cold War, and US relations with China. He was appointed by President Johnson to the President's Commission on Civil Disorders in 1967, where his work on housing discrimination influenced the 1968 Civil Rights Act. After leaving the Senate, he continued to advocate for open housing as the head of the National Low-Income Housing Coalition. Senator Brooke left the Senate to lead the National Low-Income Housing Coalition. He received prestigious honors such as the Presidential Medal of Freedom and authored a biography titled Bridging The Divide: My Life. Senator Brooke, a racial pioneer, demonstrated that barriers can be overcome with commitment and strength of character. He devoted his life to serving others and made significant contributions to society. His life and accomplishments serve as inspiring proof that people can be elected based on qualifications, not race. Senator Brooke received prestigious honors and authored a biography before leaving the Senate. The Congressional Gold Medal presentation is authorized by the Speaker of the House and the President pro tempore of the Senate. The Congress authorizes the presentation of a gold medal to Edward William Brooke III for his exceptional service to the nation. The Secretary of the Treasury will design and strike the medal. Duplicates in bronze may be sold, and the medals hold national significance. SEC. 5. The medals struck under this Act are national medals and considered numismatic items. SEC. 6. The United States Mint Public Enterprise Fund will cover the costs of the medals, and proceeds from the sale of duplicate bronze medals will be deposited into the Fund.
